thread.title: 11 Reasons to Visit India During Monsoon Season!

author: Alyssa Pinsker
title: 11 Reasons to Visit India During Monsoon Season!
text:
reddit 
I love traveling in India and I chose to arrive this time during the "monsoon" season, which might sound intimidating to an American, but it is simply the name of a cloud which visits the sub-continent and brings much needed rains to keep rolling fields fresh and emerald. It also visits the beach down in Goa and even the desert up in Rajasthan cools down a bit. 
So, June until September is the rainy season in India, but monsoon may actually be the best time it to visit India. The South is where it begins. It's best to visit lush, green places like Kerala and Tamil Nadu. But, even up north in the desert Rajasthan great monsoon package deals exist to lure luxe visitors to the palaces when it rains in the desert. The weather is cool, humid and breezy with showers, rain is considered to be highly romantic and everything is in bloom! Here are five reasons why monsoon is the best time to see luxury India for a pittance: 
1. Monsoon proves to have the lowest rates for flying to India, and even government trains and planes prove to be more affordable. See www.cleartrip.com or kayak.com for deals. 
2. Once you've landed, shop Monsoon Sales for smart clothes and exotic finds. FabIndia's Monsoon Sale which started July 19th and lasts through to September is just one example of a monsoon sale. www.fabindia.com 
3. Monsoon packages for luxury and five star hotels like the Taj can get you VIP treatment for as low as $60 a night. Check out Taj Hotel Vivanta: Fort Aguada in Anjuna, Goa. Goa's famous beaches might be the last place you think to visit India during monsoon, swimming might not be encouraged (but it is possible!) However, Monsoon packages on the Taj Vivanta's forty four acres ensure even more attentive care and pampering during the low season. Stay in a cozy Villa and watch movies on LCD TV's or go trekking or even rifle shooting around the Fort Aguada. Take a private yoga class or do Indian bodywork special to Viva Spa. Other perks include huge bathtubs, soft bathrobes and 24 hour butler service. vivantabytaj.com 
3. Since you can afford it, might as well experience the iconic Taj Mahal Palace in Mumbai or its attached neighbor, the Tower. This living art museum is the first Taj, and oldest luxury hotel in the city and boasts golden domes outside and insider are chandeliers, Persian rugs, and velvet lounge chairs. Inside is an art gallery, jewelry showroom, International bookstore and high tea daily. Marble stairs take you into rooms fitted with royal comfort and overlook the ocean and Mumbai's bustling historical and commercial hub. Having a 24 hour concierge, spa with Indian yoga and Ayurveda, salon and a gym that will actually make you want to work out, might extend your stay. Weekend rates are less expensive than weekdays. http://www.tajhotels.com/luxury/grand-palaces-and-iconic-hotels/the-taj-mahal-palace-mumbai/overview.html 
4. Monsoon releases: lots of Bollywood movies are released in time for cuddling with loved ones and some chai and popcorn in the theater or at home. English subtitles for Hindi might be harder to find, but other Indian languages almost always have them. Go to a stunning multiplex in Mumbai's legendary Plaza Cinema. Times here: http://www.filmipop.com/mumbai/theatre/plaza-cinema-dadar-west/1227 
5. It's the best time for Ayurveda. Ayurveda, the ancient science of life, dictates that monsoon time is when we start our purifying massages. Ayurveda incidentally originated in the lush, green state of Kerala, where the monsoon clouds begins. Skin always looks dewy and glowing. Yoga is easier too, as bodies are more flexible, monsoon is a good time to book an Ayurvedic treatment. Try the ultra luxurious Kalari Ayurvedic "Hospital": http://www.kalarikovilakom.com/index.htm 
6. Monsoon is romantic! Monsoon is a popular time for Indian honeymooners, as the misty rains and sleepy weather can lull one into the sensual. Take advantage of the romance and book a romantic mountain cottage in Munnar The Windermere Hotel in situated on a tea hill plantation station famous for its spiraling hills of tea and cardamom. This boutique hotel is a plantation destination which boasts a 365 degree view of the villages rolling green hills from their property. Fine linens and minimalist d√©cor help to focus on the spectacular nature around you. Take a tea plantation tour and be sure to see Top Hill station and Echo Point's waterfalls. http://windermeremunnar.com/ 
7. Nearby is Spice Village in Perriyar, Kerala which just happens to be located on a wildlife preserve in the forest. Monsoon is the most spectacular time to see Perriyar's jungle. The swimming pool boasts bottled water that you can drink, as it's oxygenated without chlorine. The kitchen serves spiced everything down to "masala wine" (Sula Indian white, lemon, cinnamon and a hint of sugar) at its continental and Indian buffet dinners. Take a bullock ride to nearby Tamil Nadu on a riskshaw led by two bulls, or take a trek to spot actual tigers, and panthers and leopards at the nearby tiger preserve, or just stay in with spiced coffee "poda kappi" found only in these hill towns. http://www.cghearth.com/spice-village 
8. Speaking of coffee, now is the time to enjoy "Monsoon Malabar," coffee beans only available during the rainy season. Indian's coffee consumption has doubled in the past 25 years, and most of the beans are exported to Italy. Enjoy the tea plantations in Munnar and Darjeeling but check out the coffee plantations too. Tata Coffee Plantations in Coorg, Karnataka are bungalows situated amidst the misty and mystical Western Ghats mountain range. Stroll among the lush green fields, experience the coffee so legendary a man was made a saint for bringing seven bean from Saudi Arabia. Baba Budu is still worshiped by South Indians of all faiths for his bravery. Experience bird watching to adventure sports to coffee tourism; the food and drinks has authentic Coorgi delicacies and lots of coffee. http://www.plantationtrails.net/ 
9. You can stay at a palace. Since you can afford it, why not stay at an actual palace? Rajastahan is the art, culture and aesthetic capital of India and is hope to legendary palaces and havellis. The royal "blue city" Udaipur is home to the beautiful Taj Lake Palace, which seems to float gracefully on Lake Pichola, and is basically one of the most romantic hotels in the world. http://www.tajhotels.com/luxury/grand-palaces-and-iconic-hotels/taj-lake-palace-udaipur/special-offers.html 
10. You can enjoy Pondicherry without the sweltering heat. Maison Perumal in Pondicherry, Tamil Nadu is a divine reconstructed Tamil heritage home in the Tamil quarter of a French colonial town in India. Traditional architecture includes finely sculpted mahogany furniture, stained glass and an open air dining room with a 10 square foot skylight where the sky and occasionally but rarely rains sprinkle in. While staying at this heritage home, enjoy cooking classes, a wonderful bicycle tour of Pondy, where the award-winning "Life of Pi" was filmed. http://www.cghearth.com/maison-perumal 
11. The hotel Palais de Mahe is in the French quarter of Pondicherry and has Franco-Tamil architecture. While staying in Southeast India, you will be surrounded by French language, culture and of course fashion. Inside is a wonderful fusion of the two. Enjoy a ground level heated swimming pool outside your door, raised canopy mahogany wood bed and a rooftop restaurant serving French and Indian food. Treats include wine with lunch, curry fish and halwah which are sweets made with honey and rose water. http://www.cghearth.com/palaisdemahe 
Monsoon is almost over, so enjoy it while you can!
